heisig_story: You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting woman drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bottom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes. Remembering the kanji is easy; being able to write it beautifully is another thing.

koohiiStory2: My mother taught me that a woman should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The radical for woman and the kanji for woman are exactly the same.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: When you think of a woman, think of Jo-Anne („Åò„Çá), though she usually goes by just "Jo."
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Whenever the reading „Åò„Çá comes up, we will use the character Jo-Anne. She's quite a short woman, which is to help us differentiate „Åò„Çá from „Åò„Çá„ÅÜ (who is the giant, oafish farmhand Jourm). „Åò„Çá is a smaller lady, „Åò„Çá„ÅÜ is a giant man.
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Pictograph of a woman.  See how curvy (and slightly pointy I suppose) she is?
origin_of_ch_char_book: As mentioned before, (Â•≥, n√º, woman; daughter) depicts a young woman sitting on her knees and holding her hands together politely. When she grows up, she becomes a man‚Äôs wife. The difference between the unmarried young woman and the married woman is the hairstyle. (Â¶ª, qi=ch‚Äôi, wife) depicts a woman who is sitting on her knees with her hair held by a hand . In the past, when a woman got married, she raised her hair up in a pigtail and fixed it with a rod-like hairpin. Thus this character means a ‚Äòmarried woman‚Äô or a ‚Äòwife‚Äô.
humanum_full_description_en:
A woman with a gold inscription on her knees and toes, her buttocks on the heels, her hands folded on her chest and slightly drooping. Today's Japanese and Korean women still have this sitting posture, retaining the ancient Chinese customs. In the later period, the inscription was easy to write, and gradually lost the kneeling position of pressing the hips and heels. In addition, the words "Â•≥" and " mother " in the Jia Jin inscriptions are mixed, and there are examples of reading "Â•≥" as " mother ". "Said Wen": "Women, women. Pictograms. Wang Yu said. All women belong to women."

There are five usages of Oracle. One means the daughter of a man and a woman. Second, read as " mother ", which means the mother of parents. Third, read " No ", which means no. Fourth, it is read as " every ", which is commonly used as " regret " to express regret. 5. Used as a place name. There are four usages of bronze inscriptions. One, it means women, the teacher: "Senior women, sheep and cattle". Second, read as " mother ", meaning mother. Si Mu Wu Fang Ding: "Si Nu (Mother) E". 3. Used as a second-person pronoun, later in the classics as " Ru ", Kuan Ling Fangyi: "Today, I am the only one (Ru)." Fourth, read as " like ", meaning like, Zhongshan Wangding: "Things are foolish women (like) wisdom".
humanum_short_description_en: The shape of a woman sitting on a kneeling like a golden inscription. The original meaning is a woman.
